pros: Best experience of working in the field, interacting with local stakeholders and overall growth.
cons: Less pay, secluded project areas.

pros: Work culture is really good
cons: There is not much cons

pros: good teammates with nice office
cons: volatile work, could work in management

job_title: Assistant Programmer Officer in New Delhi
pros: - Exposure - Good networking
cons: - Low pay; much less than industry standards

pros: Exposure that's it Team work great
cons: They don't pay well at all They don't even value work life balance especially the fundraising team They make the team work 6 days and beyond 8 hours and makes you compensate for a leave that you take and can make you come to office or go to field even on a public holiday

review_title: Nice organization to work with for conservation
pros: - Excellent colleagues and team environment - Exposure to multiple arena of conservation
cons: - Some teams work in silos - Insecurities - Way to slow

pros: Good environment to work in
cons: Management can be a little better

pros: Good company and great at team work
cons: everything was good and healthy

job_title: Senior Manager- Social Development in Bengaluru
pros: Good working atmosphere, good leave policy and brand value
cons: Too much hierarchy, low pay

review_title: WWF India : A company that doesn't want to innovate and grow out of the shell.
pros: You work alot and You learn alot. Internationally famous. Work under the big brand name of WWF.
cons:
No innovation
No growth opportunities. 
Redundant work
Work in silos , typical hierarchical structure
High work pressure.
Bootlicking

pros: Great repository of information for those who care about conservation. State offices and field researchers largely pleasant to interact with
cons:
Awful work environment. No true leadership wherever you look. Directors will play favourites or compete with each other to the point of harassing a perceived competitor's team member. Few managers are even megalomaniacal
Needlessly bureaucratic- they even keep a name register for the coffee machine. 
No long term vision and inclination to innovate. They just want to maintain the status quo at all costs. They are more concerned about having their way within WWF than working for the cause.

pros: Good work-life balance and the opportunity to engage in exciting field work. The brand name is incredible and gives opportunities for both work and professional network.
cons: The organization is very bureaucratic, and there is very little room for learning. The staff is underpaid and is not rewarded timely. Good place for top management, but no real reward for juniors wishing to build a career.

job_title: Project In Charge in New Delhi
pros: great exposure, opportunity to learn from the best in the field. Peers and seniors are supportive.
cons: salary not very competitive with other organisation

pros: Great place for global network
cons: No growth in compensation. Very hierarchical.

review_title: Most hypocritical organisation to work for
pros: Maybe the fact that office is in central Delhi.
cons:
- India office CEO mentioned in Town Hall that everyone should come to office as COVID is just a state of mind and no one is at risk. It’s all non sense. They are covering up the cases in Office and not informing employee of COVID cases in office. The entire Management is a joke. They are just using donor’s money to pay their salaries.
Oh , there are 3 washrooms for 300 employees.

pros: Great work culture and opportunity to learn from colleagues across the offices of five continent ..
cons: Too much change goes through in WWF

pros: Best place to learn on ground level but as an internship.
cons: lot of relocating and field work

pros:
Great set of people,amazing work, a good peer group and superiors who guide you.
Food available inside the building and located in the heart of the city near the UN and other important places.
Flexible working hours.
Great exposure and an amazing brand name.
Amazing work culture and the best values I've ever seen.
cons:
Since it is a non profit,salary isn't high.
Office is not like a huge corporates but gives a very homely feel.
Food isnt great so got to eat out if you want a good meal.
Some of the computers are outdated.
No wifi access provided .

pros: Supportive work culture and values; Flexibility of Working Hours; Steep learning curve; Friendly attitude of the team member; Travel & networking opportunities
cons: Can improve from the current 'very good' status to 'the best' by improving salary packages, and intercultural/international exposure

review_title: Possibility to do good work or no work at all. depends on department manager
pros:
Good access to other people working in Environmental conservation. 
Very interesting work done by field staff
cons:
Salary
management- there is no coordination of work done by different departments
very slow paced work most of the time

pros:
Biggest Conservation Org
Reach across the country 
Dedicated personnel
cons:
Low salaries
Hierarchical structures can be an issue sometimes

pros: Nice projects to save wildlife in all over the world
cons: I learned many things while I was working for Wwf INDIA

pros: about WWF-India: supportive work environment, congenial culture, great colleagues, unique work on conservation
cons: bureaucratic decision making, power centre, no delegation, salaries not benchmarked, slow growth,

pros: Very good employer, employee get good benifits during the tenure
cons: Need more attention towards implementation of work on ground, Never acknowledge your work once you leave the organisation
